I believe this song has it very clear in the lyrics... It's like, someone does what he/she likes and goes out to do it as best they can, and in their own way... and then get side-tracked following money (light of golden treasure) and then the frustration of facing his/her own mistakes and not having anyone else to blame but themselves...

The first unforgiven was the one unforgiven by society.
The second unforgiven was the one unforgiven by his/her mate.
This, the ultimate unforgiven, is the self-unforgiven... The one who can't forgive himself for what he's done...

So far Metallica are impressing me with a different sound than they had so far, and i have no oppinion formed. One thing I am tired of hearing is: Better than St Anger. 

St Anger IS, musically, not as good as what metallica had us used to, but it must be heard in context. St. Anger is a public vent of all the poison in Metallica. You just watch the documentary (Some kind of monster) to understand that... The sound comes out crude and raw and unrefined just like a feeling. Just like a spontaneous punch.

At least that's my oppinion. And in that context, the whole album fits like a glove.

Before I heard the song, i told myself not to carry any expectations in case Iâd be disappointed. I'm far from it, the transession from the piano, trumpet, guitar and drum intro is hauntingly beautiful and sends shivers up my spine and the hairs rising on my head and arms. 

As for the song meaning, here's my 2 cents. 
The first song was about a pariah's childhood and all the demons and negative experiences he encountered through his upbringing, inflicted by society and his parents.

The second song was about the pariah finding a person whom he felt he could share his burden to and they could provide him with the hope of being forgiven, as their reaction to his experiences would be free of judgement as they are "unforgiven" too. 

And this song is possibly about him accepting how he will remain unforgiven, unless he himself forgives all those who inflicted damage upon him. His present and his future are marked and influenced by the demons of his past. He realises that he can finally gain redemption through forgiving others, allowing him to let go of the anger, sadness, bitterness, resentment that continues to overshadows his present. 

"How could he know this new dawnâs light
Would change his life forever?
Set sail to sea but pulled off course
By the light of golden treasure"
The first line makes reference to where the ballad last left off (Unforgiven II i.e.), He has past through the door and embraced the light. The light of a new dawn symbolising the hope of gaining forgiveness, fresh beginnings, rebirth of one's being spiritually, emotionally, and mentally. 
I like how the concept of his journey of his life is represented through the symbolism of the "sea". 
"Set sail to sea but pulled off course" makes me think he planned on living his life through the highs and lows of the waves (obstacles) he encounters along the way until the light of "golden treasure" inspired him change course. The light symbolising "hope", the "golden treasure" symbolic of the greatest treasure he seeks. Redemption. 

"Was he the one causing pain
With his careless dreaming?"
I think he's wondering to himself if he, himself, is also guilty of contributing to the negativity thatâs accumulated over the years, through the decisions and actions he's made. 

"Been afraid, always afraid
Of the things heâs feeling"
I get the impression that this bit is speaking of the person's life in general. How the fear of embracing his "feelings" (of whatever emotion) controlled his decisions, actions, life etc. not allowing him to be human. 

"He could just be gone
He would just sail on
He would just sail on"
He can either let his fear give him the courage to end his life (gone) or let it motivate him to fight on (sail on). The use of second person narrations (i.e. "He") suggests that he's speaking of the past, the person he once was before coming to acceptance of the circumstances of the present.

"How can I be lost?
If Iâve got nowhere to go?"
From here on, the narration used is first person, marking the circumstances of the present. To state the obvious he's unsure of what course of direction he should take in his life, only he hasn't made any plans to allow him to take action and move forward. He finds it a bit ironic considering he feels lost when he's not trying to go anywhere in particular, or achieve anything. 

"Searched for seas of gold
How come itâs got so cold?
How can I be lost?"
"gold", "cold", are probably just for rhyming, maybe he's lived his life striving for forgiveness, with the fire of ambition. But now, it's as though his flame of ambition for redemption has died out and left him feeling "cold" (indifferent, apathetic, despairing) after a few failures.

"In remembrance I relive
And how can I blame you
When itâs me I canât forgive?"
He finally realises he's unforgiven because he hasn't retuned the favour and forgiven those who have harmed him (this is what distinguishes/separates the "he" from the "I", the past frame of mind he was in to the new perception he has developed at present). His memories and the pain he feels haunts him, and he can only let go of this negativity until he forgives. You realise that when you forgive others, you allow yourself to be free of the pain and resentment you have attached to the things they have done to you. You finally let yourself be free of the weight of these emotions and feel redeemed. "To err is human, to forgive is divine.â 

"These days drift on inside a fog
Itâs thick and suffocating"
He lives his life surrounded by a haze of confusion as to if he should forgive his demons and allow himself to let go, and it seems to consume every breath he takes.

"This seeking life outside its hell
Inside intoxicating"
I don't really get this but i think the quote 'This seeking life', He's speaking of the force that compels him to look for balance and peace, compared to inner state of his mind and emotions, that are like drugs, something that keeps weighing him down. 

"Heâs run aground like his life
Waterâs much too shallow
Slipping fast down with the ship
Fading in the shadows now"
I'm not sure what this means either but "he's run aground like his life" makes me think his life seems to be stuck in the past. There's no sense of movement towards the future. 
He believes he's "sailed" (lived) his life on "shallow water", shallow water could symbolise how he never really got anywhere, because he never managed to go further towards "deep waters", meaning he never really crossed any "seas" towards "gold treasure" (forgiveness). 
The "ship" symbolising the ambition or the feelings that drove him to achieve his dreams, goals, or seek redemption has "sunk", "he" (his past persona) along with it. 

"A castaway
Blame all gone away
Blame gone away"
The experience of feeling "lost" has allowed him to remove feelings of blame and resentment he shifted on his perpetrators. He has been cleansed/changed by the "sea" (the journey of seeking redemption).

"Forgive me, forgive me
Why canât I forgive me?"
He has yet to forgive his demons, before he can heal and finally gain redemption.

comment_37:
Seems to me as this person has been "sailing" (going to work, getting on with day to day life) for a long time, untill one day "pulled of course by the light of golden treasure".

Since then that person have changed and his partner (wife, girlfriend, good friend) "been afraid of his careless dreaming... been afriad... of the things he's feeling" - partner is worried for him, because he's not what he used to be, as he's been "causing pain with his careless dreaming" - may be dreaming like he wants to quit his usual life and concentrate on that freshly found "golden treasure". And I think he does that as "He would just sail on. He would just sail on."

Then "How can I be lost. If I've got nowhere to go" that "plain" sailing (usual/normal/boring life) isn't taking him anywhere, so he got nowhere to go. He also now have "Searched the seas of gold" however to his surprise("How come") that sea (different life, new things etc.)"it's got so cold". Then he says again that he can't be lost, because he's got nowhere to go - same old again.

"How can I blame you
When it's me I can't forgive" - he still can't forgive himself for what he's done/caused/what happened because of him (as he tells later.)

"These days drift on inside a fog
It's thick and suffocating
This seeking life outside its hell"

Now that he doesn't know what to do - he can't seem to find "his thing", that old "sailing" has turned into drifting on days in a fog (springs into mind a line from Master of Puppets (...drift on numbered days...)), which is thick and suffocating - seems like this hell/life he isn't enjoying (because he's seeking something new) will be with him forever.

"This seeking life outside its hell
Inside intoxicating"

He seeks something new/better/different "outside its hell" - outside his usual life, because he's "suffocating" and "intoxicating" (may be reffering to drugs, alcohol), as if he's dying.

"He's run aground
Like his life
Water's much too shallow
Slipping fast
Down with the ship
Fading in the shadows
Now a castaway"

His life has stoped/changed dramatically, because "water is much too shallow" - water supports ship on the water, otherwise ship sinks. So with our person, water got too shallow and he can't sail anymore, so he became a castaway, his ship hit the ground and can't sail anymore, because

"They've all gone away
They've gone away"

This is the crucial part - people who've been supporting him, thanks to who he was able to "sail on" (e.g. live) have all gone away and now the water became too shallow for sailing. This has been caused by his careless (selfish) dreaming, because he got attracted by that golden treasure, and in most books/films golden treasures represent greed and isolation.

Now he can't forgive himself for what happened and is not blaming his partner, however he realises that it's all his fault.

So, make sure you don't ignore people around you, appreciate their help and don't forget about those who made you who you are when you find that "golden treasure" and you be ok.

How could he know this new dawn's light
Would change his life forever?
Set sail to sea, but pulled off course
By the light of golden treasure
======================
This relates to the lyrics of Unforgiven II. At the end of that song, the man stumbles off into the light. He didn't expect the light to change his life completely, however. He considered his life's trip to be straightforward, like a wavy sea, but a light of forgiveness lit up his path. He considered this light a golden treasure.

Was he the one causing pain
With his careless dreaming?
Been afraid, always afraid
Of the things he's feeling
==================
Was he perhaps the one causing pain to himself, and not society? Perhaps his dreams were not realistic? He has always been afraid to express what he felt and what he knew, but is he still afraid?

He could just be gone
He would just sail on

============
The sadness that defined him for all of his life is lost. He is just living his life. He will live on.

How can I be lost, if I've got nowhere to go?
Search for seas of gold
How come it's got so cold?
====================

When it's me I can't forgive?

this song is about self forgivenss. this is my perception of this track.

"how could he know this new dawns light..."  of course the new dawns light is of the golden treasure, which is temptations in life. examples: eve taking the apple or fortune, etc... and of course the sea represents life.

"was he the one causing pain..."  the careless dreams are the goals we want to achieve in life that we feel will make us "complete" examples: fame, to be recognized, to be a higher person. this way of life causes an imbalance in the world, hence what goes on today.

"been afraid always afraid..."  always moving forward, in life, through the mind/ thoughts,/ carless dreams, rather than living life moment by moment. feeling is of the moment. 

"he could just be gone..."  going about life in this way will get you nowhere. we have the choice to either go about life by moment (sail on) or temptation. its OUR choice. so dont blame anyone but your own self.

"how can i be lost if ive got nowhere to go?"  this is the whole meaning of the song, setting a direction in life (the careless dreaming) leads to pain withIN. this all ties to self honesty.

"searched for seas of gold..."  of course, gold is the temptations in life, this way of living seems to be "normal" but it truely is a "cold" way to live.

Here's how I view each song:

The Unforgiven:
This song is about being beaten, and eventually dying with in *or being numb inside* and believing that there is nothing good in this whole world. The person in the first song went through most of his life hated, and picked on. However, he kept dreaming of finding a way out, and he did.

The Unforgiven II:
This song I have already commented on about 30 minutes ago, but the person from the first song finds someone just like him, and he dubbed her Unforgiven II *too*. He thought that since they were both Unforgiven that she would relate to him, but he found disappointment when she betrays him. He kills her, leaving a key to happiness outside of this world with her death.

The Unforgiven III:
As the Unforgiven II had a line in it that said "But now I see the sun, Now I see the sun, yes now I see it", this song begins with "How could he know this new dawn's light Would change his life forever?" Once the person from the previous two songs killed the woman, he was pulle doff course with the dawn's new light. "Set sail to sea, but pulled of course by the light of golden treasure" When he killed her, he was pulled of course from obtaining entrance to "heaven", and is now sailing on the River Styx, aka he's in Hell, or his soul is damn to hell. Now he can never forgive himself for what he'd done to her, and he can't find the forgiveness he needs to get to the holy light. His vessel *his ship* runs aground and he goes down with it, which symbolizes his own final death. Now he is lost in hell, or limbo. But he'll never be able to forgive himself, thus for ever remaining the Unforgiven

idk..That's my point of view. I love all three songs, and I wouldn't stop listening to them even if Metallica were banned all over the world.

comment_81:
First of all I'm a huge fan of Metallica !!
Second of all, this song can have a lot of meanings: the lyrics allow a variety of interpretations. The interpretation that fits best for me is one that the protagonist is a person who's going through difficult things in his life (he's almost or possibly completely depressive), and he doesn't know how to change them. Verse by verse:

"How could he know this new dawn's life
Would change his life forever?"
Something happened in the protagonist's life that completely changed everything in his life. So he starts thinking that he couldn't ever know that that happening would bring so much difficulty to him.

"Set sail to sea, but pulled off course
By the light of golden treasure."
He was living the best way he could, and then (again), something that seemed harmless or really good for him ("treasure") brought a lot of bad things to him ("pulled off course")

"Was he the one causing pain
With his careless dreaming?
Been afraid, always afraid,
Of the things he's feeling."
Then when starts thinking about all his life, his starts wondering if every bad things are his fault, and if he acted differently or if he wasn't so afraid of himself and his feelings that his constantly trying to hide, everything wouldn't be so hard.

"He could just be gone.
He would just sail on
He would just sail on."
When thinking for a solution, he tries to runaway of it all ("be gone"). But then he realizes all he can do is go on living.

"How can I be lost
If I've got nowhere to go"
He has no idea of how he can solve all his problems ("nowhere to go").

"Searched the seas of gold
How come it's got so cold?
How can I be lost
In remembrance I relive"
He starts reliving everything he's passed through, trying to understand how everything got so hard ("How come it's got so cold?"

"So how can I blame you
When it's me I can't forgive"
He can't forgive himself for wrong things he did.

"These days drift on inside a fog
It's thick and suffocating
This seeking life outside its hell
Inside intoxicating"
All his days are a constant pain: when he's alone it's "intoxicating", and when he's with others everything is "hell". That is: whether he's thinking about his situation or trying to solve it, everything's just too harsh.

"He's run aground
Like his life
Water's much too shallow
Slipping fast
Down with the ship
Fading in the shadows"
So he just starts drowing in suffering

"Now a castaway
They've all gone away
They've gone away"
Everyone's abandoned him. Here either people actually did it - they can't live with him anymore because they can't stand his state - or he just imagines that no one cares about him, or he simply doesn't trust anyone, so he feels abandoned.

Forgive me
Forgive me not
Forgive me
Forgive me not
Forgive me
Forgive me not
Forgive me
Forgive me, why can't I forgive me
He tries to forgive himself, and clearly he gets angry at himself because he can't do it, he keeps blaming himself for his mistakes.

Well, there it is, my interpretation. It's a really nice song, too bad the lyrics are so sad in the way i interpret them. As I said before, it may have lots of different meanings, I just think the one I did fits correctly into the verses.
